sections.title: Posthumous tributes
sections.paragraphs:
[[File:Turing statue Surrey.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Statue of Turing at the [[University of Surrey]]<ref name="univsurrey"/>]]
Various institutions have paid tribute to Turing by naming things after him including:

{{Div col|colwidth=35em}}
* The computer room at [[King's College, Cambridge]], Turing's alma mater, is called the Turing Room.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kings.cam.ac.uk/study/facilities/academic.html |title=Academic facilities |publisher=King's College Cambridge |accessdate=12 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505052323/http://www.kings.cam.ac.uk/study/facilities/academic.html |archive-date=5 May 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>
* The Turing Room at the [[University of Edinburgh School of Informatics|University of Edinburgh's School of Informatics]] houses a bust of Turing by [[Eduardo Paolozzi]], and a set (No. 42/50) of his Turing prints (2000).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.synth.co.uk/images/paolozzi2.html |title=Turing prints (2000) |publisher=Synth.co.uk |date=24 September 2000 |accessdate=31 October 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102102224/http://www.synth.co.uk/images/paolozzi2.html |archive-date=2 November 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref>
* The [[University of Surrey]] has a statue of Turing on their main piazza<ref name="univsurrey"/> and one of the buildings of Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences is named after him.<ref name=SurreyCelebration>{{cite web |url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/computing/news/events/2012/a_celebration_of_the_code_breaker_alan_turing.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225111618/http://www.surrey.ac.uk/computing/news/events/2012/a_celebration_of_the_code_breaker_alan_turing.htm|title=A celebration of the code breaker – Alan Turing |publisher=University of Surrey |accessdate=24 December 2013|archivedate=25 December 2013}}</ref>
* [[Istanbul Bilgi University]] organises an annual conference on the theory of computation called "Turing Days".<ref name="v3">{{cite web | url = http://www.v3.co.uk/v3-uk/news/2381568/the-imitation-game-10-surprising-facts-about-bletchley-park-genius-alan-turing/page/2 | title = The Imitation Game: 10 surprising facts about Bletchley Park genius Alan Turing | accessdate = 17 April 2015 | publisher = V3.co.uk | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150416133943/http://www.v3.co.uk/v3-uk/news/2381568/the-imitation-game-10-surprising-facts-about-bletchley-park-genius-alan-turing/page/2 | archive-date = 16 April 2015 | url-status = live }}</ref>
* The [[University of Texas at Austin]] has an honours computer science programme named the Turing Scholars.<ref name="texturingschol">{{cite web| url = https://www.cs.utexas.edu/turing-scholars| title = Turing Scholars Program at the University of Texas at Austin| accessdate = 17 May 2015| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150502092325/http://www.cs.utexas.edu/turing-scholars| archive-date = 2 May 2015| url-status = live}}</ref>
* In the early 1960s, [[Stanford University]] named the sole lecture room of the Polya Hall Mathematics building "Alan Turing Auditorium".<ref name="stanforduniv">{{cite web | url = http://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/text/Knuth_Don_X4100/PDF_index/k-8-pdf/k-8-u2679-Stanford-Comp-Dedication.pdf | title = Polya Hall, Stanford University | accessdate = 14 June 2011 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120324211759/http://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/text/Knuth_Don_X4100/PDF_index/k-8-pdf/k-8-u2679-Stanford-Comp-Dedication.pdf | archive-date = 24 March 2012 | url-status=dead | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
* One of the amphitheatres of the Computer Science department ([[Laboratoire d'Informatique Fondamentale de Lille|LIFL]]<ref name="lifl">{{cite web |url=http://www.lifl.fr/ |title=Laboratoire d'Informatique Fondamentale de Lille |accessdate=3 December 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722014047/http://www.lifl.fr/ |archive-date=22 July 2010 |url-status=live }}</ref>) at the [[Université Lille 1|University of Lille]] in northern France is named in honour of Alan M. Turing (the other amphitheatre is named after [[Kurt Gödel]]).
* The [[University of Washington]] has a computer laboratory named after Turing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Turing Center|url=http://turing.cs.washington.edu/|publisher=University of Washington|date=10 June 2016|access-date=11 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603084446/http://turing.cs.washington.edu/|archive-date=3 June 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* [[Oxford Brookes University]] has a building named after Turing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Department of Computing and Communication Technologies Research Lecture Series lecture 4|url=https://www.brookes.ac.uk/about-brookes/events/department-of-computing-and-communication-technologies-research-lecture-series-lecture-4/|publisher=Oxford Brooke's University|date=10 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170916004447/https://www.brookes.ac.uk/about-brookes/events/department-of-computing-and-communication-technologies-research-lecture-series-lecture-4/|archive-date=16 September 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref>
* Alan Turing Road in the [[Surrey Research Park]]<ref name=SurreyCelebration /> and the Alan Turing Way, part of the Manchester inner ring road. Alan Turing road in Loughborough<ref>{{cite news|last=Cooksey|first=Katie|title=Alan Turing: Manchester celebrates pardoned genius|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-25499447|accessdate=24 December 2013|work=BBC News|date=24 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224234405/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-25499447|archive-date=24 December 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> are named after Turing.
* [[Carnegie Mellon University]] has a granite bench, situated in the Hornbostel Mall, with the name "A.M. Turing" carved across the top, "Read" down the left leg, and "Write" down the other.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A._M._Turing_bench,_Carnegie_Mellon_University,_Pittsburgh_PA,_USA.jpg|title=English: Bench constructed in honor of Alan Turing, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh Pennsylvania USA campus|date=22 February 2012|accessdate=15 July 2019|via=Wikimedia Commons|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204091448/https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:A._M._Turing_bench,_Carnegie_Mellon_University,_Pittsburgh_PA,_USA.jpg|archive-date=4 February 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The [[University of Oregon]] has a bust of Turing on the side of Deschutes Hall, the computer science building.<ref name="Oregon">{{cite web|url=http://www.mathcomp.leeds.ac.uk/turing2012/files/oregon.html|title=Turing at the University of Oregon|accessdate=1 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114151918/http://www.mathcomp.leeds.ac.uk/turing2012/files/oregon.html|archive-date=14 January 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The [[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]] has a road and a square named after Turing (Chemin Alan Turing and Place Alan Turing).<ref name="epfl">{{cite web|url=http://plan.epfl.ch/?zoom=20&recenter_y=5863918.36573&recenter_x=730628.82407&layerNodes=fonds,batiments,labels,information,parkings_publics,arrets_metro|title=Turing at the EPFL|accessdate=6 January 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112043444/http://plan.epfl.ch/?zoom=20&recenter_y=5863918.36573&recenter_x=730628.82407&layerNodes=fonds,batiments,labels,information,parkings_publics,arrets_metro|archive-date=12 January 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The [[Faculty of Informatics and Information Technologies]] Slovak University of Technology in [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]], has a lecture room named "Turing Auditorium".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://is.stuba.sk/mistnosti/?zobrazit_mistnost=2472;areal=2;budova=172;klic=2472;mistnostpodrobne=1;lang=en|title= Lecture rooms|accessdate= 28 February 2015|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150402120524/http://is.stuba.sk/mistnosti/?zobrazit_mistnost=2472;areal=2;budova=172;klic=2472;mistnostpodrobne=1;lang=en|archive-date= 2 April 2015|url-status= live}}</ref>
* The [[Paris Diderot University]] has a lecture room named "Amphithéâtre Turing".<ref>{{cite news|title=Thèses soutenues Université Paris Diderot|url=http://www.univ-paris-diderot.fr/sc/site.php?bc=recherche&np=6_THESE|agency=University Paris Diderot|date=10 June 2016|access-date=11 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701194422/http://www.univ-paris-diderot.fr/sc/site.php?bc=recherche&np=6_THESE|archive-date=1 July 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The Faculty of Mathematics and Computer Science at the [[University of Würzburg]] has a lecture hall named "Turing Hörsaal".<ref name="wueuniv">{{cite web|url=http://www.mathematik-informatik.uni-wuerzburg.de/en/sonstiges/directions_maps/faculty_of_mathematics_and_computer_science/computer_science_building/ground_floor/|title=Turing Hörsaal at University of Würzburg|accessdate=21 July 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728061208/http://www.mathematik-informatik.uni-wuerzburg.de/en/sonstiges/directions_maps/faculty_of_mathematics_and_computer_science/computer_science_building/ground_floor/|archivedate=28 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
* The [[Paul Sabatier University]] in Toulouse has a lecture room named "Amphithéâtre Turing" (Bâtiment U4).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.univ-tlse3.fr/campus/campus-198550.kjsp?RH=RUB01&|title=Université Toulouse III - Paul Sabatier - Campus|first=Sabine|last=DELPECH|website=www.univ-tlse3.fr|accessdate=6 February 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612184541/http://www.univ-tlse3.fr/campus/campus-198550.kjsp?RH=RUB01&|archive-date=12 June 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The largest conference hall at the [[Amsterdam Science Park]] is named Turingzaal.<ref>{{cite web |title=Facilities / Catering and conference |url=http://www.amsterdamsciencepark.nl/location-facilities/facilities/catering-and-conference/ |publisher=[[Amsterdam Science Park]] |accessdate=11 January 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111124907/http://www.amsterdamsciencepark.nl/location-facilities/facilities/catering-and-conference/ |archivedate=11 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
* [[King's College London]]'s School of Natural and Mathematical Sciences awards the Alan Turing Centenary Prize.<ref>{{cite news|title=King's College London Prizes|url=https://www.kcl.ac.uk/campuslife/services/grad/ceremonies/afterceremony/gradlist/Awards%20by%20Faculty/Prizes-Jan-2016.pdf|publisher=KCL|date=10 June 2016|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808223926/https://www.kcl.ac.uk/campuslife/services/grad/ceremonies/afterceremony/gradlist/Awards%20by%20Faculty/Prizes-Jan-2016.pdf|archivedate=8 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
* The [[University of Kent]] named the Turing College after him at their Canterbury campus.<ref>{{cite news|title=How the University of Kent's new Turing College got its name|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent-business/county-news/recognising-shrouded-genius-of-computer-27479/|publisher=Kent Online|date=10 June 2016|access-date=11 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813094110/http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent-business/county-news/recognising-shrouded-genius-of-computer-27479/|archive-date=13 August 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The campus of the [[École polytechnique]] has a building named after Turing; it is a research centre whose premises are shared by the [[École Polytechnique]], the [[INRIA]] and [[Microsoft]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inria.fr/en/|title=INRIA|year=2012|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325010427/https://www.inria.fr/en/|archive-date=25 March 2017|access-date=19 March 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The [[University of Toronto]] developed the [[Turing programming language]] in 1982, named after Turing.
* The campus of [[University of Campinas|State University of Campinas]] in Brazil has an avenue, one of its largest, named after Turing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Unicamp Science and Technology Park|url=http://www.inova.unicamp.br/sites/default/files/images/Inova_brochuraPCTU_ingles.pdf|publisher=Inova|date=1 July 2016|access-date=1 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807043320/http://www.inova.unicamp.br/sites/default/files/images/Inova_brochuraPCTU_ingles.pdf|archive-date=7 August 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* [[Ghent University]] named a computer room after Turing, in their department of Computer Science and Applied Mathematics.<ref>{{cite web| title=Computer rooms at the university of Ghent| url=http://www.ugent.be/we/nl/faculteit/pc-knooppunt| access-date=12 November 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112141644/http://www.ugent.be/we/nl/faculteit/pc-knooppunt| archive-date=12 November 2016| url-status=live}}</ref>
* [[Nvidia]] unveiled their line of [[GeForce]] Graphics Cards based on the [[Turing (microarchitecture)|Turing microarchitecture]], which in turn was named after Turing. The architecture introduces the first consumer products capable of real-time raytracing, which has been a longstanding goal of the computer graphics industry.
* [[Turing House School]] in London<ref>{{cite web |title=About Our Name |url=https://www.turinghouseschool.org.uk/ourname.php |website=Turing House School |accessdate=21 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190713211250/https://www.turinghouseschool.org.uk/ourname.php |archive-date=13 July 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> and one of the '[[House system|houses]]' at [[Wellacre Academy]] in Manchester are named after him.<ref>{{cite web |title=House System |url=http://www.wellacre.org/parents-carers-and-students/house-system/ |website=Wellacre Academy |accessdate=21 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191019052601/http://www.wellacre.org/parents-carers-and-students/house-system/ |archive-date=19 October 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref>
* [[Redmond, Washington]], the location of [[Microsoft Corporation]]'s headquarters, named a street adjacent to the Microsoft main Campus after Turing, along with streets named for other historically significant scientists and inventors.<ref>{{cite web| title=Overlake Village Infrastructure Planning | url=https://www.redmond.gov/607/Overlake-Village-Infrastructure-Planning| access-date=21 December 2019 | url-status=live}}</ref>
{{colend}}

A biography published by the [[Royal Society]] shortly after Turing's death,<ref name=frs/> while his wartime work was still subject to the [[Official Secrets Act]], recorded:
{{quote| Three remarkable papers written just before the war, on three diverse mathematical subjects, show the quality of the work that might have been produced if he had settled down to work on some big problem at that critical time. For his work at the Foreign Office he was awarded the OBE.<ref name="frs"/>}}
Since 1966, the [[Turing Award]] has been given annually by the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] for technical or theoretical contributions to the computing community. It is widely considered to be the computing world's highest honour, equivalent to the Nobel Prize.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acm.org/press-room/news-releases-2007/turingaward/|title=ACM'S Turing Award Prize Raised To $250,000|publisher=[[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] press release|date=27 July 2007|accessdate=16 October 2008|author=Geringer, Steven|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230233653/http://www.acm.org/press-room/news-releases-2007/turingaward/|archivedate=30 December 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

On 23 June 1998, on what would have been Turing's 86th birthday, his biographer, [[Andrew Hodges]], unveiled an official [[English Heritage]] [[blue plaque]] at his birthplace in Warrington Crescent, London, later the Colonnade Hotel.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.turing.org.uk/bio/oration.html | title=Unveiling the official Blue Plaque on Alan Turing's Birthplace | accessdate=26 September 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927175849/http://www.turing.org.uk/bio/oration.html | archive-date=27 September 2006 | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.blueplaque.com/detail.php?plaque_id=348 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013143212/http://www.blueplaque.com/detail.php?plaque_id=348 | archivedate=13 October 2007 | title=About this Plaque – Alan Turing | accessdate=25 September 2006}}</ref> To mark the 50th anniversary of his death, a memorial plaque was unveiled on 7 June 2004 at his former residence, Hollymeade, in [[Wilmslow]], Cheshire.<ref>{{openplaque|3276}}</ref>
[[File:Turing Plaque.jpg|thumb|right|A [[blue plaque]] marking Turing's home at [[Wilmslow]], Cheshire]]

On 13 March 2000, [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] issued a set of postage stamps to celebrate the greatest achievements of the 20th century, one of which carries a portrait of Turing against a background of repeated 0s and 1s, and is captioned: "1937: Alan Turing's theory of digital computing". On 1 April 2003, Turing's work at [[Bletchley Park]] was named an [[List of IEEE milestones|IEEE Milestone]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Milestones:Code-breaking_at_Bletchley_Park_during_World_War_II,_1939-1945 |title=Milestones:Code-breaking at Bletchley Park during World War II, 1939–1945 |author=IEEE History Center |year=2003 |work=IEEE Global History Network |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=29 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402205029/http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Milestones:Code-breaking_at_Bletchley_Park_during_World_War_II%2C_1939-1945 |archive-date=2 April 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 28 October 2004, a bronze statue of Turing sculpted by [[John W. Mills]] was unveiled at the [[University of Surrey]] in [[Guildford]], marking the 50th anniversary of Turing's death; it portrays him carrying his books across the campus.<ref name="univsurrey">{{cite press release|url=http://portal.surrey.ac.uk/press/oct2004/281004a/ |title=The Earl of Wessex unveils statue of Alan Turing |date=October 2004 |publisher=University of Surrey |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023193441/http://portal.surrey.ac.uk/portal/page?_pageid=799%2C277813&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL |archive-date=23 October 2007 |url-status=dead |df= }}</ref>

Turing was one of four mathematicians examined in the BBC documentary entitled ''Dangerous Knowledge'' (2008).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/documentaries/features/dangerous-knowledge.shtml|title=Dangerous Knowledge|publisher=BBC Four|date=11 June 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102045025/http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/documentaries/features/dangerous-knowledge.shtml|archive-date=2 November 2011}}</ref> The ''[[Princeton Alumni Weekly]]'' named Turing the second most significant alumnus in the history of [[Princeton University]], second only to President [[James Madison]]. A 1.5-ton, life-size statue of Turing was unveiled on 19 June 2007 at Bletchley Park. Built from approximately half a million pieces of Welsh [[slate]], it was sculpted by [[Stephen Kettle]], having been commissioned by the American billionaire [[Sidney Frank]].<ref>[http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/454075/article.html Bletchley Park Unveils Statue Commemorating Alan Turing] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227171427/http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/454075/article.html |date=27 February 2012 }}, Bletchley Park press release, 20 June 2007.</ref>

Turing has been honoured in various ways in [[Manchester]], the city where he worked towards the end of his life. In 1994, a stretch of the [[A6010 road]] (the [[Manchester]] city intermediate ring road) was named "Alan Turing Way". A bridge carrying this road was widened, and carries the name Alan Turing Bridge. A [[Alan Turing Memorial|statue of Turing]] was unveiled in Manchester on 23 June 2001 in [[Sackville Park]], between the University of Manchester building on Whitworth Street and [[Canal Street, Manchester|Canal Street]]. The memorial statue depicts the "father of computer science" sitting on a bench at a central position in the park. Turing is shown holding an apple. The cast bronze bench carries in relief the text 'Alan Mathison Turing 1912–1954', and the motto 'Founder of Computer Science' as it could appear if encoded by an [[Enigma machine]]: 'IEKYF ROMSI ADXUO KVKZC GUBJ'. However, the meaning of the coded message is disputed, as the 'u' in 'computer' matches up with the 'u' in 'ADXUO'. As a letter encoded by an enigma machine can not appear as itself, the actual message behind the code is uncertain.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://benosteen.wordpress.com/2010/09/23/what-does-the-code-on-the-alan-turing-memorial-actually-say/|title=What does the code on the Alan Turing Memorial actually say?|date=2010-09-23|work=Random Hacks|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628125202/https://benosteen.wordpress.com/2010/09/23/what-does-the-code-on-the-alan-turing-memorial-actually-say/|archive-date=28 June 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
[[File:Sackville Park Turing plaque.jpg|thumb|right|Turing memorial statue plaque in [[Sackville Park]], Manchester]]
A plaque at the statue's feet reads 'Father of computer science, mathematician, logician, wartime codebreaker, victim of prejudice'. There is also a [[Bertrand Russell]] quotation: "Mathematics, rightly viewed, possesses not only truth, but supreme beauty—a beauty cold and austere, like that of sculpture." The sculptor buried his own old [[Amstrad]] computer under the [[plinth]] as a tribute to "the godfather of all modern computers".<ref name="computerburied">{{cite news | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/computer-buried-in-tribute-to-genius-1186583 | title=Computer buried in tribute to genius | work=Manchester Evening News | date=17 February 2007 | accessdate=7 December 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104022559/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/computer-buried-in-tribute-to-genius-1186583 | archive-date=4 November 2013 | url-status=live }}</ref>

In 1999, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named Turing as one of the [[Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century|100 Most Important People of the 20th century]] and stated, "The fact remains that everyone who taps at a keyboard, opening a spreadsheet or a word-processing program, is working on an incarnation of a Turing machine."<ref name=AFP>{{cite news |title=Alan Turing – Time 100 People of the Century |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,990624,00.html |work=Time |quote=Providing a blueprint for the electronic digital computer. The fact remains that everyone who taps at a keyboard, opening a spreadsheet or a word-processing program, is working on an incarnation of a Turing machine. |first=Paul |last=Gray |date=29 March 1999 |access-date=10 January 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119181237/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,990624,00.html |archive-date=19 January 2011 |url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2002, Turing was ranked twenty-first on the BBC's poll of the [[100 Greatest Britons]] following a UK-wide vote.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2208671.stm | title = 100 great British heroes | date = 21 August 2002 | work = BBC News | access-date = 26 September 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101104074956/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2208671.stm | archive-date = 4 November 2010 | url-status = live }}</ref> In 2006, British writer and mathematician [[Ioan James]] chose Turing as one of twenty people to feature in his book about famous historical figures who may have had some of the traits of [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>{{cite book|author= James, Ioan M.|title=Asperger's Syndrome and High Achievement|url=https://books.google.com/?id=SZ-p4GOdJIgC|publisher=Jessica Kingsley|year=2006|isbn=978-1-84310-388-2 }}</ref> In 2010, actor/playwright [[Jade Esteban Estrada]] portrayed Turing in the solo musical, ''Icons: The Lesbian and Gay History of the World, Vol. 4''. In 2011, in ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s "My hero" series, writer [[Alan Garner]] chose Turing as his hero and described how they had met while out jogging in the early 1950s. Garner remembered Turing as "funny and witty" and said that he "talked endlessly".<ref>{{cite news | author-link=Alan Garner | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/nov/11/alan-turing-my-hero-alan-garner | title=My Hero: Alan Turing | work=Saturday Guardian Review | date=12 November 2011 | accessdate=23 November 2011 | last=Garner | first=Alan | page=5 | ref=harv | location=London | archive-url=https://archive.today/20170328084346/https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/nov/11/alan-turing-my-hero-alan-garner | archive-date=28 March 2017 | url-status=live }}</ref> In 2006, Turing was named with online resources as an LGBT History Month Icon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lgbthistorymonth.com/alan-turing |title=Alan Turing |publisher=LGBTHistoryMonth.com |date=20 August 2011 |accessdate=15 January 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009190932/http://www.lgbthistorymonth.com/alan-turing |archive-date=9 October 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2006, Boston [[GLBT pride|Pride]] named Turing their Honorary Grand Marshal.<ref name="bostonpride">{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonpride.org:80/honorarymarshal.php |title=Boston Pride: Honorary Grand Marshal |accessdate=23 November 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060619181036/http://www.bostonpride.org/honorarymarshal.php |archivedate=19 June 2006 |df=dmy |url-status=dead }}</ref>

[[File:Alan Turing Memorial Closer.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Turing memorial statue in [[Sackville Park]], Manchester]]

The logo of [[Apple Inc.]] is often erroneously referred to as a tribute to Turing, with the bite mark a reference to his death.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/logos-that-became-legends-icons-from-the-world-of-advertising-768077.html |title=Logos that became legends: Icons from the world of advertising|work=The Independent |location=UK |accessdate=14 September 2009 | date=4 January 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091003003651/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/logos-that-became-legends-icons-from-the-world-of-advertising-768077.html| archivedate= 3 October 2009 | url-status=live}}</ref> Both the designer of the logo<ref>{{cite web | url = http://creativebits.org/interview/interview_rob_janoff_designer_apple_logo | title = Interview with Rob Janoff, designer of the Apple logo | publisher = creativebits | accessdate = 14 September 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171024013734/http://creativebits.org/interview/interview_rob_janoff_designer_apple_logo | archive-date = 24 October 2017 | url-status = live }}</ref> and the company deny that there is any homage to Turing in the design.<ref>{{Harvnb|Leavitt|2007|p=280}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://navasazeez.com/blog/apple-logo-alan-turing/ |title=Turing and the Apple logo |accessdate=25 December 2015 |date=25 July 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151225165517/http://navasazeez.com/blog/apple-logo-alan-turing/ |archivedate=25 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Stephen Fry]] has recounted asking [[Steve Jobs]] whether the design was intentional, saying that Jobs' response was, "God, we wish it were."<ref>[http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120620-the-turing-test-of-time "Science & Environment – Alan Turing: Separating the man and the myth"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623064706/http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120620-the-turing-test-of-time |date=23 June 2012 }}. BBC. Retrieved 23 June 2012.</ref> In February 2011, Turing's papers from the Second World War were bought for the nation with an 11th-hour bid by the [[National Heritage Memorial Fund]], allowing them to stay at Bletchley Park.<ref>{{cite news |author=Halliday, Josh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/feb/25/turing-papers-auction-bid-bletchley |title=Turing papers to stay in UK after 11th-hour auction bid at |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=29 May 2011 |date=25 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224024223/http://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/feb/25/turing-papers-auction-bid-bletchley |archive-date=24 December 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2012, Turing was inducted into the [[Legacy Walk]], an outdoor public display that celebrates LGBT history and people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacyprojectchicago.org/2012_INDUCTEES.html|title=2012 INDUCTEES|author=Salvo, Victor|publisher=The Legacy Project|accessdate=1 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709012921/http://www.legacyprojectchicago.org/2012_INDUCTEES.html|archive-date=9 July 2017|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/pride/2014/10/11/photos-7-lgbt-heroes-honored-plaques-chicagos-legacy-walk|title=PHOTOS: 7 LGBT Heroes Honored With Plaques in Chicago's Legacy Walk|publisher=Advocate.com|accessdate=1 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017121512/http://www.advocate.com/pride/2014/10/11/photos-7-lgbt-heroes-honored-plaques-chicagos-legacy-walk|archive-date=17 October 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>

The song "Alan et la Pomme", by [[francophone]] singer-songwriter [[Salvatore Adamo]], is a tribute to Turing.<ref>{{cite AV Media|title=Alan et la Pomme – Salvatore Adamo|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WkPopfcnEO4|via=YouTube|accessdate=26 December 2013|author=Kamiab, Farbod|date=20 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616022912/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WkPopfcnEO4|archive-date=16 June 2014|url-status=live}}{{better source|date=December 2017}}</ref> Turing's life and work featured in a BBC children's programme about famous scientists, ''[[Absolute Genius with Dick and Dom]]'', first broadcast on 12 March 2014.

On 17 May 2014, the world's first work of public art to recognise Turing as gay was commissioned in Bletchley, close by to Bletchley Park where his war-time work was carried out. The commission was announced to mark [[International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia]]. The work was unveiled at a ceremony on Turing's birthday, 23 June 2014, and is placed alongside busy Watling Street, the old main road to London, where Turing himself would have passed by on many occasions. On 22 October 2014, Turing was inducted into the [[NSA Hall of Honor]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Cryptologic Hall of Honor – Alan Turing|url=https://www.nsa.gov/about/cryptologic-heritage/historical-figures-publications/hall-of-honor/2014/aturing.shtml|publisher=National Security Agency|accessdate=14 February 2017|date=22 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215120125/https://www.nsa.gov/about/cryptologic-heritage/historical-figures-publications/hall-of-honor/2014/aturing.shtml|archive-date=15 February 2017|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|title=Five Cryptologists Added to NSA/CSS Cryptologic Hall of Honor|url=https://www.nsa.gov/news-features/press-room/press-releases/2014/cryptologists-added-to-hall-of-honor.shtml|publisher=National Security Agency|accessdate=14 February 2017|date=22 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215121448/https://www.nsa.gov/news-features/press-room/press-releases/2014/cryptologists-added-to-hall-of-honor.shtml|archive-date=15 February 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

In 2014 Turing was one of the inaugural honorees in the [[Rainbow Honor Walk]], a [[List of halls and walks of fame|walk of fame]] in San Francisco's [[Castro District, San Francisco|Castro neighborhood]] noting [[LGBTQ]] people who have "made significant contributions in their fields."<ref name=":022">{{Cite web|url=https://quirkytravelguy.com/lgbt-walk-fame-rainbow-honor-san-francisco/|title=The Rainbow Honor Walk: San Francisco's LGBT Walk of Fame|last=Shelter|first=Scott|date=March 14, 2016|website=Quirky Travel Guy|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190728105852/https://quirkytravelguy.com/lgbt-walk-fame-rainbow-honor-san-francisco/|archive-date=28 July 2019|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sfist.com/2014/09/02/castros_rainbow_honor_walk_dedicate/|title=Castro's Rainbow Honor Walk Dedicated Today: SFist|date=September 2, 2014|website=SFist - San Francisco News, Restaurants, Events, & Sports|access-date=13 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190810075052/https://sfist.com/2014/09/02/castros_rainbow_honor_walk_dedicate/|archive-date=10 August 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaysonoma.com/2016/07/second-lgbt-honorees-selected-for-san-franciscos-rainbow-honor-walk/|title=Second LGBT Honorees Selected for San Francisco's Rainbow Honor Walk|last=Carnivele|first=Gary|date=July 2, 2016|website=We The People|access-date=2019-08-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190812121249/http://www.gaysonoma.com/2016/07/second-lgbt-honorees-selected-for-san-franciscos-rainbow-honor-walk/|archive-date=12 August 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>

In February 2019, in the BBC eight-part TV series ''[[Icons: The Greatest Person of the 20th Century]]'', Turing was voted by viewers to be the Greatest Person.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0by86tp|title=BBC Two - Icons: The Greatest Person of the 20th Century|website=BBC|accessdate=6 February 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190206163339/https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0by86tp|archive-date=6 February 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>

In July 2019, the [[Bank of England]] announced that Turing's portrait would appear on the next edition of the [[Bank of England £50 note]], to be released in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-48962557|title=New face of the £50 note is revealed|first=Kevin|last=Peachey|date=15 July 2019|accessdate=15 July 2019|via=www.bbc.co.uk|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190715103104/https://www.bbc.com/news/business-48962557|archive-date=15 July 2019|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Press |first1=The Associated |title=Codebreaker Alan Turing to be face of new British banknote |url=https://www.richmond.com/ap/business/codebreaker-alan-turing-to-be-face-of-new-british-banknote/article_311ebf0d-95df-5ad9-9348-0ad5e1703948.html |website=Richmond Times-Dispatch |accessdate=16 July 2019 |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190716024442/https://www.richmond.com/ap/business/codebreaker-alan-turing-to-be-face-of-new-british-banknote/article_311ebf0d-95df-5ad9-9348-0ad5e1703948.html |archive-date=16 July 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> He is the first openly gay person to appear on paper currency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dallasvoice.com/alan-turing-will-be-new-face-of-british-50-pound-note/|title=Alan Turing will be new face of British 50 pound note|first=|date=2019-07-15|website=Dallas Voice|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190716172519/https://dallasvoice.com/alan-turing-will-be-new-face-of-british-50-pound-note/|archive-date=16 July 2019|access-date=2019-09-07}}</ref>

sections.title: Centenary celebrations
sections.paragraphs:
{{main|Alan Turing Year}}
[[File:David Chalmers, delivering a talk at De La Salle University-Manila, March 27, 2012.jpg|thumb|right|[[David Chalmers]] on stage for an Alan Turing Year conference at [[De La Salle University]], Manila, 27 March 2012]]
To mark the 100th anniversary of Turing's birth, the Turing Centenary Advisory Committee (TCAC) co-ordinated the [[Alan Turing Year]], a year-long programme of events around the world honouring Turing's life and achievements. The TCAC, chaired by [[S. Barry Cooper]] with Turing's nephew Sir John Dermot Turing acting as Honorary President, worked with the University of Manchester faculty members and a broad spectrum of people from Cambridge University and [[Bletchley Park]].

On 23 June 2012, Google featured an interactive [[Google doodle#Google Doodle|doodle]] where visitors had to change the instructions of a Turing Machine, so when run, the symbols on the tape would match a provided sequence, featuring "Google" in [[ITA2|Baudot-Murray code]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2012/06/google-doodle-honors-alan-turing/1 |title=Google Doodle honors Alan Turing |newspaper=USA Today |date=22 June 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623234009/http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2012/06/google-doodle-honors-alan-turing/1 |archive-date=23 June 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The Bletchley Park Trust collaborated with [[Winning Moves]] to publish an Alan Turing edition of the board game [[Monopoly (game)|Monopoly]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/the-northerner/2012/sep/24/alan-turing-monopoly|title=Playing Monopoly with Alan Turing|last=Cooper|first=S. Barry|date=2012-09-24|work=The Guardian|access-date=2019-11-08|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The game's squares and cards have been revised to tell the story of Turing's life, from his birthplace in Maida Vale to Hut 8 at Bletchley Park.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-19543039 | title = Special Monopoly edition celebrates Alan Turing's life | work = BBC News | accessdate = 10 September 2012 | date = 10 September 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120912035628/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-19543039 | archive-date = 12 September 2012 | url-status = live }}</ref> The game also includes a replica of an original hand-drawn board created by [[William Newman (computer scientist)|William Newman]], son of Turing's mentor, [[Max Newman]], which Turing played on in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/668532|title=Bletchley Park Launches Special Edition Alan Turing Monopoly Board|accessdate=13 September 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912171549/http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/news/docview.rhtm/668532|archive-date=12 September 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>

In the [[Philippines]], the [[De La Salle University College of Liberal Arts#Academic departments of CLA|Department of Philosophy]] at [[De La Salle University]]-Manila hosted Turing 2012, an international conference on philosophy, artificial intelligence, and cognitive science from 27 to 28 March 2012 to commemorate the centenary birth of Turing.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/03/24/12/dlsu-host-intl-summit-philosophy | title=DLSU to host int'l summit on philosophy | publisher=ABS-CBN.com | date=24 March 2012 | accessdate=18 December 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122091551/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/03/24/12/dlsu-host-intl-summit-philosophy | archive-date=22 January 2014 | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/255746/scitech/science/the-thinking-machine-a-philosophical-analysis-of-the-singularity | title=The Thinking Machine: A philosophical analysis of the Singularity | work=GMA News Online | date=21 April 2012 | accessdate=18 December 2013 | author=Layug-Rosero, Regina | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219045638/http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/255746/scitech/science/the-thinking-machine-a-philosophical-analysis-of-the-singularity | archive-date=19 December 2013 | url-status=live }}</ref> [[Madurai]], India held celebrations with a programme attended by 6,000 students.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/making-themselves-heard/article3605820.ece | title=Making themselves heard | work=The Hindu | date=5 July 2012 | accessdate=31 October 2013 | author=Shankar, M. Gopi | location=Chennai, India | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102224101/http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/making-themselves-heard/article3605820.ece | archive-date=2 November 2013 | url-status=live }}</ref>

[[File:Alan Turing Olympic Torch.jpg|thumbnail|The [[London 2012]] [[2012 Summer Olympics torch relay|Olympic Torch]] flame was passed on in front of Turing's statue in Manchester on his 100th birthday.]]
There was a three-day conference in Manchester in June, the [[Alan Turing Centenary Conference]], a two-day conference in San Francisco, organised by the ACM, and a birthday party and Turing Centenary Conference in Cambridge organised at [[King's College, Cambridge]], and the University of Cambridge, the latter organised by the association [[Computability in Europe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/feb/23/northerner-alan-turing-centenary-celebrations |title=The Northerner: Alan Turing, computer pioneer, has centenary marked by a year of celebrations |publisher=The Guardian |website=theguardian.com |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030134311/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/feb/23/northerner-alan-turing-centenary-celebrations |archive-date=30 October 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum in London]] launched a free exhibition devoted to Turing's life and achievements in June 2012, to run until July 2013.<ref>{{cite news | date=18 June 2012 | accessdate=23 June 2012 | authorlink=Rory Cellan-Jones | first1=Rory | first2=David | last1=Cellan-Jones | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18459979 | title=Enigma? First look at Alan Turing exhibition (report with video preview) | work=[[BBC News]] | last2=Rooney (curator) | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005074333/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18459979 | archive-date=5 October 2012 | url-status=live }}</ref> In February 2012, the [[Royal Mail]] issued a stamp featuring Turing as part of its "Britons of Distinction" series.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2012/01/alan-turing-to-feature-in-britons-of-distinction-stamp-series/ | title=Codebreaker Alan Turing gets stamp of approval | work=Gizmodo | date=2 January 2012 | accessdate=2 January 2012 | author=Cutlack, Gary | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108050910/http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2012/01/alan-turing-to-feature-in-britons-of-distinction-stamp-series/ | archive-date=8 January 2012 | url-status=live }}</ref> The [[London 2012]] [[2012 Summer Olympics torch relay|Olympic Torch]] flame was passed on in front of Turing's statue in [[Sackville Gardens]], Manchester, on the evening of 23 June 2012, the 100th anniversary of his birth.

On 22 June 2012 [[Manchester City Council]], in partnership with the [[The Lesbian and Gay Foundation in Manchester|Lesbian and Gay Foundation]], launched the Alan Turing Memorial Award, which will recognise individuals or groups who have made a significant contribution to the fight against homophobia in Manchester.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1581770_centenary-award-tribute-to-enigma-codebreaker-alan-turing|title=Centenary award tribute to "enigma" codebreaker Alan Turing.|last=Anon|date=22 June 2012|work=Manchester Evening News|publisher=MEN media|accessdate=22 June 2012|location=Manchester|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625002855/http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1581770_centenary-award-tribute-to-enigma-codebreaker-alan-turing|archive-date=25 June 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>

At the [[University of Oxford]], a new course in [[Computer Science]] and Philosophy was established to coincide with the centenary of Turing's birth.<ref>{{  Cite journal|title=Computer Science and philosophy |publisher=University of Oxford |url=http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/admissions/ugrad/Computer_Science_and_Philosophy |accessdate=23 June 2013 |ref=harv |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330233859/http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/admissions/ugrad/Computer_Science_and_Philosophy |archivedate=30 March 2013 }} A new undergraduate degree course, with its first students having started in 2012, the centenary of Alan Turing's birth.</ref>

Previous events have included a celebration of Turing's life and achievements, at the University of Manchester, arranged by the British Logic Colloquium and the [[British Society for the History of Mathematics]] on 5 June 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dcs.warwick.ac.uk/bshm/archive/meetings.html |title=BSHM Meetings (1992–2007) |publisher=University of Warwick |accessdate=24 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020192059/http://www.dcs.warwick.ac.uk/bshm/archive/meetings.html |archive-date=20 October 2011 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sections.title: Portrayal
sections.paragraphs:
====In theatre====
[[File:Benedict Cumberbatch 2013 TIFF (headshot).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Benedict Cumberbatch]] portrayed Turing in the 2014 film ''[[The Imitation Game]]'']]
* ''[[Breaking the Code]]'' is a 1986 play by [[Hugh Whitemore]] about Turing. The play ran in [[West End theatre|London's West End]] beginning in November 1986 and on Broadway from 15 November 1987 to 10 April 1988. In these performances Turing was played by [[Derek Jacobi]]. The Broadway production was nominated for three [[Tony Award]]s including Best Actor in a Play, Best Featured Actor in a Play, and Best Direction of a Play, and for two [[Drama Desk Award]]s, for Best Actor and Best Featured Actor. Turing was again portrayed by Jacobi in [[Breaking the Code (TV movie)|the 1996 television film adaptation]] of ''Breaking the Code''.<ref name="BBC-mutlitiude">{{cite news|title=Alan Turing: A multitude of lives in fiction|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18472563|work=BBC News|date=23 June 2012|access-date=21 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180707172444/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18472563|archive-date=7 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In 2012, in honour of the Turing Centennial, [[American Lyric Theater]] commissioned an operatic exploration of the life and death of Turing from composer Justine F. Chen and librettist David Simpatico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://altnyc.org/new-operas-for-new-audiences/the-turing-project/|title=The Life and Death(s) of Alan Turing – a new opera|publisher=American Lyric Theater|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122025250/http://altnyc.org/new-operas-for-new-audiences/the-turing-project/|archivedate=22 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Titled ''The Life and Death(s) of Alan Turing'', the opera is a historical fantasia on the life of Turing. In November 2014, the opera and several other artistic works inspired by Turing's life were featured on [[Studio 360]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studio360.org/story/alan-turing-man-and-myth/|title=Alan Turing, Man and Myth – Studio 360|work=studio360|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122025209/http://www.studio360.org/story/alan-turing-man-and-myth/|archivedate=22 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The opera received its first public performance in January 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openculture.com/2017/01/the-real-alan-turing-comes-to-life-in-a-new-opera.html|title=Alan Turing Gets Channeled in a New Opera|first=Josh|last=Jones|website=www.openculture.com|date=16 January 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611063802/http://www.openculture.com/2017/01/the-real-alan-turing-comes-to-life-in-a-new-opera.html|archive-date=11 June 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

====In literature====
* In [[William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'' the Turing police have jurisdiction over AIs. (1984)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/24/books/science-fiction.html|title=Science Fiction|date=24 November 1985|work=The New York Times|accessdate=25 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009083934/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/24/books/science-fiction.html|archive-date=9 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* Turing is featured in the [[Neal Stephenson]] novel ''[[Cryptonomicon]]'' (1999).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/23/reviews/990523.23garnert.html|title=Click Here|accessdate=25 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417020700/http://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/23/reviews/990523.23garnert.html|archive-date=17 April 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The 2000 [[Doctor Who]] novel ''[[The Turing Test (novel)|The Turing Test]]'' features Turing and the writer [[Graham Greene]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/books/turingtest/ "Turing Test"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726113755/http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/books/turingtest/ |date=26 July 2018 }}, BBC, 24 October 2014.</ref>
* The 2006 novel ''[[A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines]]'' contrasts fictionalised accounts of the lives and ideas of Turing and [[Kurt Gödel]].<ref>{{citation|title=Obsessive-Genius Disorder|journal=[[The New York Times]]|first=Jim|last=Holt|date=3 September 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/03/books/review/Holt.t.html|access-date=4 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170623182825/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/03/books/review/Holt.t.html|archive-date=23 June 2017|url-status=live}}.</ref>
* The 2009 novel ''Fall of Man in Wilmslow'' by [[David Lagercrantz]] is a fictional account of the investigation of Alan Turing's death written from the point of view of the investigating police officer.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Hopley|first=Claire|title=BOOK REVIEW: 'Fall of Man in Wilmslow'|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/13/book-review-fall-of-man-in-wilmslow/|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=13 July 2016|accessdate=20 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190620114314/https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/13/book-review-fall-of-man-in-wilmslow/|archive-date=20 June 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The 2015 novel ''[[Speak (Hall novel)|Speak]]'', written by [[Louisa Hall]], includes a series of fictional letters written from Turing to his best friend's mother throughout his life, detailing his research about artificial intelligence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Review: 'Speak' by Louisa Hall|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-speak-louisa-hall-20150917-story.html|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=31 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314091434/http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-speak-louisa-hall-20150917-story.html|archive-date=14 March 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Waldman|first1=Katy|title='Speak,' by Louisa Hall|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/speak-by-louisa-hall.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=31 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001235314/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/speak-by-louisa-hall.html|archive-date=1 October 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In the graphic novel series ''[[Über (comics)|Über]]'', in which a fictionalised version of WWII plays out involving [[superhuman]] soldiers called "Tank-Men", Turing is one of the researchers as well as a Tank-Man himself.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite web|last1=Truitt|first1=Brian|title='Uber' explores monsters and men of World War II|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2013/05/13/kieron-gillen-uber-comic-book-series/2149289/|website=USA Today|accessdate=13 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912083140/https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2013/05/13/kieron-gillen-uber-comic-book-series/2149289/|archive-date=12 September 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
*Turing is featured in [[Ian McEwan]]'s 2019 novel, ''[[Machines Like Me]]'' {{ISBN|978-1787331662}}.

====In music====
* Electronic music duo [[Matmos]] released an EP titled ''For Alan Turing'' in 2006, which was based on material commissioned by Dr. Robert Osserman and David Elsenbud of the [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vague-terrain.com/?release=for-alan-turing|title=Matmos release ''For Alan Turing''|publisher=Vague Terrain|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328194945/http://vague-terrain.com/?release=for-alan-turing|archive-date=28 March 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In one of its tracks, an original Enigma Machine is sampled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prefixmag.com/news/track-review-matmos-enigma-machine-for-alan-turing/8032/|title=Track Review: Matmos – Enigma Machine For Alan Turing|last=Sheppard|first=Justin|date=7 September 2006|work=Prefix Mag|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207225755/http://www.prefixmag.com/news/track-review-matmos-enigma-machine-for-alan-turing/8032/|archive-date=7 February 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In 2012, Spanish group [[Hidrogenesse]] dedicated their LP ''Un dígito binario dudoso. Recital para Alan Turing'' (''A dubious binary digit. Concert for Alan Turing'') to the memory of the mathematician.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2012/05/25/tentaciones/1337949017_223917.html|title=Hidrogenesse, 'Un dígito binario dudoso'|last=Rodríguez Ramos|first=Javier|date=29 May 2012|work=El País – Cultura|language=Spanish|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531012511/http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2012/05/25/tentaciones/1337949017_223917.html|archive-date=31 May 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
* A musical work inspired by Turing's life, written by [[Neil Tennant]] and [[Chris Lowe]] of the [[Pet Shop Boys]], entitled ''A Man from the Future'', was announced in late 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2012/09/13/pet-shop-boys-speak-out-about-alan-turing|title=Pet Shop Boys Working on Alan Turing Project|last=Portwood|first=Jerry|date=13 September 2012|work=Out magazine|accessdate=29 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231000135/http://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2012/09/13/pet-shop-boys-speak-out-about-alan-turing|archive-date=31 December 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> It was performed by the Pet Shop Boys and [[Juliet Stevenson]] (narrator), the BBC Singers, and the BBC Concert Orchestra conducted by Dominic Wheeler at the [[BBC Proms]] in the Royal Albert Hall on 23 July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04b2m2y|title=BBC Radio 3 – BBC Proms, 2014 Season, Prom 8: Pet Shop Boys|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903212740/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04b2m2y|archive-date=3 September 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>
* ''Codebreaker'' is also the title of a choral work by the composer James McCarthy. It includes settings of texts by the poets [[Wilfred Owen]], [[Sara Teasdale]], [[Walt Whitman]], [[Oscar Wilde]] and [[Robert Burns]] that are used to illustrate aspects of Turing's life. It was premiered on 26 April 2014 at the [[Barbican Centre]] in London, where it was performed by the [[Hertfordshire Chorus]], who commissioned the work, led by [[David Temple]] with the soprano soloist Naomi Harvey providing the voice of Turing's mother.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hertfordshire Chorus – James McCarthy: Codebreaker, a life in music|url=http://www.classical-music.com/event/hertfordshire-chorus-james-mccarthy-codebreaker|work=Classical Music Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141126093739/http://www.classical-music.com/event/hertfordshire-chorus-james-mccarthy-codebreaker|archive-date=26 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|SRMNi4_th-0|Codebreaker}}</ref>

====In film====
* ''[[Codebreaker (film)|Codebreaker]]'', original UK title ''Britain's Greatest Codebreaker'', is a TV film that aired on 21 November 2011 by [[Channel 4]] about Turing's life. It had a limited release in the US beginning on 17 October 2012. The story is told as a discussion between Turing and his psychiatrist Dr. Franz Greenbaum. The story is based on journals maintained by Greenbaum and others who have studied Turing's life as well as some of his colleagues.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8904124/Britains-Greatest-Codebreaker-the-tragic-story-of-Alan-Turing.html|title=Britain's Greatest Codebreaker: the tragic story of Alan Turing|author=Chris Harvey|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=10 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051753/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8904124/Britains-Greatest-Codebreaker-the-tragic-story-of-Alan-Turing.html|archive-date=11 January 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The historical drama film ''[[The Imitation Game]]'', directed by [[Morten Tyldum]] and starring [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as Turing and [[Keira Knightley]] as [[Joan Clarke]], was released in the UK on 14 November 2014 and released theatrically in the US on 28 November 2014. The story concentrates on the period of Turing's life where he breaks the [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] code with other codebreakers in [[Bletchley Park]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=Brian|title='The Imitation Game' Will Stuff Theaters This Holiday Weekend – Specialty Box Office Preview|url=https://deadline.com/2014/11/the-imitation-game-will-stuff-theaters-this-holiday-weekend-specialty-box-office-preview-1201297279/|website=Deadline|access-date=26 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129032530/http://deadline.com/2014/11/the-imitation-game-will-stuff-theaters-this-holiday-weekend-specialty-box-office-preview-1201297279/|archive-date=29 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NYT-20141030-CM">{{cite news |last=Charles |first=McGrath |title=The Riddle Who Unlocked the Enigma – 'The Imitation Game' Dramatises the Story of Alan Turing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/02/movies/the-imitation-game-dramatizes-the-story-of-alan-turing.html |date=30 October 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102153646/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/02/movies/the-imitation-game-dramatizes-the-story-of-alan-turing.html |archive-date=2 November 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/oct/09/the-imitation-game-alan-turing-gay| title = The Imitation Game: the queerest thing to hit multiplexes for years?| author = Walters, Ben| date = 9 October 2014| accessdate = 14 November 2014| newspaper = The Guardian| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141115031142/http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/oct/09/the-imitation-game-alan-turing-gay| archive-date = 15 November 2014| url-status = live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/13/the-imitation-game-review-cumberbatch-turing| title = The Imitation Game review – Cumberbatch cracks biopic code| author = Bradshaw, Peter| date = 13 November 2014| accessdate = 14 November 2014| newspaper = The Guardian| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141113193547/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/13/the-imitation-game-review-cumberbatch-turing| archive-date = 13 November 2014| url-status = live}}</ref> It received the [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]] in 2015. It was a tremendous success, bringing in $233.6 million<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=imitationgame.htm|title=The Imitation Game (2014) - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|access-date=2018-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181112220458/https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=imitationgame.htm|archive-date=12 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> for a production cost of $14 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/how-weinstein-turned-imitation-game-749575|title=How The Weinstein Co. Turned 'Imitation Game' Director Into an Oscar Contender|website=The Hollywood Reporter|language=en|access-date=2018-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831104411/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/how-weinstein-turned-imitation-game-749575|archive-date=31 August 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>

sections.title: In theatre
sections.paragraphs:
[[File:Benedict Cumberbatch 2013 TIFF (headshot).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Benedict Cumberbatch]] portrayed Turing in the 2014 film ''[[The Imitation Game]]'']]
* ''[[Breaking the Code]]'' is a 1986 play by [[Hugh Whitemore]] about Turing. The play ran in [[West End theatre|London's West End]] beginning in November 1986 and on Broadway from 15 November 1987 to 10 April 1988. In these performances Turing was played by [[Derek Jacobi]]. The Broadway production was nominated for three [[Tony Award]]s including Best Actor in a Play, Best Featured Actor in a Play, and Best Direction of a Play, and for two [[Drama Desk Award]]s, for Best Actor and Best Featured Actor. Turing was again portrayed by Jacobi in [[Breaking the Code (TV movie)|the 1996 television film adaptation]] of ''Breaking the Code''.<ref name="BBC-mutlitiude">{{cite news|title=Alan Turing: A multitude of lives in fiction|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18472563|work=BBC News|date=23 June 2012|access-date=21 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180707172444/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18472563|archive-date=7 July 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In 2012, in honour of the Turing Centennial, [[American Lyric Theater]] commissioned an operatic exploration of the life and death of Turing from composer Justine F. Chen and librettist David Simpatico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://altnyc.org/new-operas-for-new-audiences/the-turing-project/|title=The Life and Death(s) of Alan Turing – a new opera|publisher=American Lyric Theater|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122025250/http://altnyc.org/new-operas-for-new-audiences/the-turing-project/|archivedate=22 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Titled ''The Life and Death(s) of Alan Turing'', the opera is a historical fantasia on the life of Turing. In November 2014, the opera and several other artistic works inspired by Turing's life were featured on [[Studio 360]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studio360.org/story/alan-turing-man-and-myth/|title=Alan Turing, Man and Myth – Studio 360|work=studio360|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122025209/http://www.studio360.org/story/alan-turing-man-and-myth/|archivedate=22 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The opera received its first public performance in January 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openculture.com/2017/01/the-real-alan-turing-comes-to-life-in-a-new-opera.html|title=Alan Turing Gets Channeled in a New Opera|first=Josh|last=Jones|website=www.openculture.com|date=16 January 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611063802/http://www.openculture.com/2017/01/the-real-alan-turing-comes-to-life-in-a-new-opera.html|archive-date=11 June 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

sections.title: In literature
sections.paragraphs:
* In [[William Gibson]]'s ''[[Neuromancer]]'' the Turing police have jurisdiction over AIs. (1984)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/24/books/science-fiction.html|title=Science Fiction|date=24 November 1985|work=The New York Times|accessdate=25 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009083934/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/11/24/books/science-fiction.html|archive-date=9 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
* Turing is featured in the [[Neal Stephenson]] novel ''[[Cryptonomicon]]'' (1999).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/23/reviews/990523.23garnert.html|title=Click Here|accessdate=25 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417020700/http://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/23/reviews/990523.23garnert.html|archive-date=17 April 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The 2000 [[Doctor Who]] novel ''[[The Turing Test (novel)|The Turing Test]]'' features Turing and the writer [[Graham Greene]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/books/turingtest/ "Turing Test"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726113755/http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/books/turingtest/ |date=26 July 2018 }}, BBC, 24 October 2014.</ref>
* The 2006 novel ''[[A Madman Dreams of Turing Machines]]'' contrasts fictionalised accounts of the lives and ideas of Turing and [[Kurt Gödel]].<ref>{{citation|title=Obsessive-Genius Disorder|journal=[[The New York Times]]|first=Jim|last=Holt|date=3 September 2006|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/03/books/review/Holt.t.html|access-date=4 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170623182825/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/03/books/review/Holt.t.html|archive-date=23 June 2017|url-status=live}}.</ref>
* The 2009 novel ''Fall of Man in Wilmslow'' by [[David Lagercrantz]] is a fictional account of the investigation of Alan Turing's death written from the point of view of the investigating police officer.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Hopley|first=Claire|title=BOOK REVIEW: 'Fall of Man in Wilmslow'|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/13/book-review-fall-of-man-in-wilmslow/|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=13 July 2016|accessdate=20 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190620114314/https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jul/13/book-review-fall-of-man-in-wilmslow/|archive-date=20 June 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The 2015 novel ''[[Speak (Hall novel)|Speak]]'', written by [[Louisa Hall]], includes a series of fictional letters written from Turing to his best friend's mother throughout his life, detailing his research about artificial intelligence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Review: 'Speak' by Louisa Hall|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-speak-louisa-hall-20150917-story.html|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=31 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314091434/http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-speak-louisa-hall-20150917-story.html|archive-date=14 March 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Waldman|first1=Katy|title='Speak,' by Louisa Hall|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/speak-by-louisa-hall.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=31 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001235314/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/books/review/speak-by-louisa-hall.html|archive-date=1 October 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In the graphic novel series ''[[Über (comics)|Über]]'', in which a fictionalised version of WWII plays out involving [[superhuman]] soldiers called "Tank-Men", Turing is one of the researchers as well as a Tank-Man himself.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite web|last1=Truitt|first1=Brian|title='Uber' explores monsters and men of World War II|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2013/05/13/kieron-gillen-uber-comic-book-series/2149289/|website=USA Today|accessdate=13 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912083140/https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2013/05/13/kieron-gillen-uber-comic-book-series/2149289/|archive-date=12 September 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
*Turing is featured in [[Ian McEwan]]'s 2019 novel, ''[[Machines Like Me]]'' {{ISBN|978-1787331662}}.

sections.title: In music
sections.paragraphs:
* Electronic music duo [[Matmos]] released an EP titled ''For Alan Turing'' in 2006, which was based on material commissioned by Dr. Robert Osserman and David Elsenbud of the [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vague-terrain.com/?release=for-alan-turing|title=Matmos release ''For Alan Turing''|publisher=Vague Terrain|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328194945/http://vague-terrain.com/?release=for-alan-turing|archive-date=28 March 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In one of its tracks, an original Enigma Machine is sampled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prefixmag.com/news/track-review-matmos-enigma-machine-for-alan-turing/8032/|title=Track Review: Matmos – Enigma Machine For Alan Turing|last=Sheppard|first=Justin|date=7 September 2006|work=Prefix Mag|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207225755/http://www.prefixmag.com/news/track-review-matmos-enigma-machine-for-alan-turing/8032/|archive-date=7 February 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* In 2012, Spanish group [[Hidrogenesse]] dedicated their LP ''Un dígito binario dudoso. Recital para Alan Turing'' (''A dubious binary digit. Concert for Alan Turing'') to the memory of the mathematician.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2012/05/25/tentaciones/1337949017_223917.html|title=Hidrogenesse, 'Un dígito binario dudoso'|last=Rodríguez Ramos|first=Javier|date=29 May 2012|work=El País – Cultura|language=Spanish|accessdate=5 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531012511/http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2012/05/25/tentaciones/1337949017_223917.html|archive-date=31 May 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
* A musical work inspired by Turing's life, written by [[Neil Tennant]] and [[Chris Lowe]] of the [[Pet Shop Boys]], entitled ''A Man from the Future'', was announced in late 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2012/09/13/pet-shop-boys-speak-out-about-alan-turing|title=Pet Shop Boys Working on Alan Turing Project|last=Portwood|first=Jerry|date=13 September 2012|work=Out magazine|accessdate=29 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231000135/http://www.out.com/entertainment/popnography/2012/09/13/pet-shop-boys-speak-out-about-alan-turing|archive-date=31 December 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> It was performed by the Pet Shop Boys and [[Juliet Stevenson]] (narrator), the BBC Singers, and the BBC Concert Orchestra conducted by Dominic Wheeler at the [[BBC Proms]] in the Royal Albert Hall on 23 July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04b2m2y|title=BBC Radio 3 – BBC Proms, 2014 Season, Prom 8: Pet Shop Boys|publisher=BBC|accessdate=1 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903212740/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04b2m2y|archive-date=3 September 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>
* ''Codebreaker'' is also the title of a choral work by the composer James McCarthy. It includes settings of texts by the poets [[Wilfred Owen]], [[Sara Teasdale]], [[Walt Whitman]], [[Oscar Wilde]] and [[Robert Burns]] that are used to illustrate aspects of Turing's life. It was premiered on 26 April 2014 at the [[Barbican Centre]] in London, where it was performed by the [[Hertfordshire Chorus]], who commissioned the work, led by [[David Temple]] with the soprano soloist Naomi Harvey providing the voice of Turing's mother.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hertfordshire Chorus – James McCarthy: Codebreaker, a life in music|url=http://www.classical-music.com/event/hertfordshire-chorus-james-mccarthy-codebreaker|work=Classical Music Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141126093739/http://www.classical-music.com/event/hertfordshire-chorus-james-mccarthy-codebreaker|archive-date=26 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|SRMNi4_th-0|Codebreaker}}</ref>

sections.title: In film
sections.paragraphs:
* ''[[Codebreaker (film)|Codebreaker]]'', original UK title ''Britain's Greatest Codebreaker'', is a TV film that aired on 21 November 2011 by [[Channel 4]] about Turing's life. It had a limited release in the US beginning on 17 October 2012. The story is told as a discussion between Turing and his psychiatrist Dr. Franz Greenbaum. The story is based on journals maintained by Greenbaum and others who have studied Turing's life as well as some of his colleagues.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8904124/Britains-Greatest-Codebreaker-the-tragic-story-of-Alan-Turing.html|title=Britain's Greatest Codebreaker: the tragic story of Alan Turing|author=Chris Harvey|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=10 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051753/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8904124/Britains-Greatest-Codebreaker-the-tragic-story-of-Alan-Turing.html|archive-date=11 January 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>
* The historical drama film ''[[The Imitation Game]]'', directed by [[Morten Tyldum]] and starring [[Benedict Cumberbatch]] as Turing and [[Keira Knightley]] as [[Joan Clarke]], was released in the UK on 14 November 2014 and released theatrically in the US on 28 November 2014. The story concentrates on the period of Turing's life where he breaks the [[Enigma machine|Enigma]] code with other codebreakers in [[Bletchley Park]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=Brian|title='The Imitation Game' Will Stuff Theaters This Holiday Weekend – Specialty Box Office Preview|url=https://deadline.com/2014/11/the-imitation-game-will-stuff-theaters-this-holiday-weekend-specialty-box-office-preview-1201297279/|website=Deadline|access-date=26 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129032530/http://deadline.com/2014/11/the-imitation-game-will-stuff-theaters-this-holiday-weekend-specialty-box-office-preview-1201297279/|archive-date=29 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="NYT-20141030-CM">{{cite news |last=Charles |first=McGrath |title=The Riddle Who Unlocked the Enigma – 'The Imitation Game' Dramatises the Story of Alan Turing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/02/movies/the-imitation-game-dramatizes-the-story-of-alan-turing.html |date=30 October 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102153646/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/02/movies/the-imitation-game-dramatizes-the-story-of-alan-turing.html |archive-date=2 November 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/oct/09/the-imitation-game-alan-turing-gay| title = The Imitation Game: the queerest thing to hit multiplexes for years?| author = Walters, Ben| date = 9 October 2014| accessdate = 14 November 2014| newspaper = The Guardian| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141115031142/http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2014/oct/09/the-imitation-game-alan-turing-gay| archive-date = 15 November 2014| url-status = live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/13/the-imitation-game-review-cumberbatch-turing| title = The Imitation Game review – Cumberbatch cracks biopic code| author = Bradshaw, Peter| date = 13 November 2014| accessdate = 14 November 2014| newspaper = The Guardian| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141113193547/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/13/the-imitation-game-review-cumberbatch-turing| archive-date = 13 November 2014| url-status = live}}</ref> It received the [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]] in 2015. It was a tremendous success, bringing in $233.6 million<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=imitationgame.htm|title=The Imitation Game (2014) - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|access-date=2018-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181112220458/https://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=imitationgame.htm|archive-date=12 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> for a production cost of $14 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/how-weinstein-turned-imitation-game-749575|title=How The Weinstein Co. Turned 'Imitation Game' Director Into an Oscar Contender|website=The Hollywood Reporter|language=en|access-date=2018-12-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831104411/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/how-weinstein-turned-imitation-game-749575|archive-date=31 August 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
